developmentContext.title: Development Context
developmentContext.content:
The Dominican Republic is a mountainous tropical country located on the border of the North Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea. The country’s land area is approximately 48,442 square kilometers with 9.65 million inhabitants. The country’s workforce is highly dependent on the services sector, being comprised of the tourism, transportation, communications and finances industries.

The institutional and normative framework of the Dominican democracy faces challenges to promote and guarantee social well-being and reduce conflicts. Women’s participation in elective positions is still low despite established quotas to ensure female representation and there is a high rate of gender-based violence. Social oversight is lacking, and the use of sustainability safeguards in the design of public policies, institutional reforms and transparency in public management is inadequate.

Like most countries in Latin America, the Dominican Republic has submitted one national communication to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) with a second one under preparation. Land use change and forestry are large contributors to GHG emissions within the sector. The emission reduction potential is large and several reforestation programs have been initiated. The Dominican Republic does not count with Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) projects in the agricultural sector, thus carbon trading opportunities can be explored. A greater emphasis on developing and applying adequate insurance mechanisms can be placed for better management of public resources in light of natural disasters in the agriculture sector.

On the adaptation side, the focus is on the potential to build resilience to climate and to increase the adaptive capacity through sustainable management of agriculture and other complementary factors (e.g. financial instruments).

successesInDevelopment.title: Successes in Development
successesInDevelopment.content:
Dominican Republic’s HDI value for 2019 is 0.756— which put the country in the high human development category. The Dominican Republic is currently one of the fastest-growing economies in the Latin American and Caribbean region, with an average gross domestic product (GDP) annual growth rate of 7.2 per cent (2014-2015). Between 1990 and 2019, the Dominican Republic’s life expectancy at birth increased by 7.5 years, mean years of schooling increased by 3.2 years and expected years of schooling increased by 2.7 years. The Dominican Republic’s GNI per capita increased by about 196.1 percent between 1990 and 2019.

Poverty has been declining, having recently recovered to levels registered before the 2003 economic crisis. At the end of 2015, 32.3 percent of the population were living in moderate poverty and 7 percent in extreme poverty, with reductions of 26.9 percent in moderate poverty and 49 percent in extreme poverty between 2006 and 2015.

challengesInDevelopment.title: Challenges in Development
challengesInDevelopment.content:
Although national human development dimensions of living standards, education and health exhibit positive trends, constraints remain. The Gini index has shown minimal distributive improvements that are not proportional to the high economic growth (falling 9.7 percent between 2000 and 2016). The 2015 Human Development Index (0.722) adjusted for inequality fell by 21.7 per cent. The main sources of inequality are in living standards (28.1 percent), education (19.9 percent) and health (16.8 percent). There are limitations in the labour market, particularly for youth and women: 47 percent of employed women work in the informal sector and receive incomes up to 39.4 percent lower than men. Moreover, agriculture is highly vulnerable to extreme weather events, this coupled with problems of land degradation in the country. Threats associated with climate change, natural hazards (hydro-meteorological and seismic) and vulnerabilities linked to insularity aggravate the challenges associated with the unsustainable management of natural and water resources.

////////////////////////////Compiled Content////////////////////////////////

DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

The Dominican Republic is a mountainous tropical country located on the border of the North Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea that shares the island of Hispaniola with its neighbor to the west, Haiti. The country’s land area is approximately 48,442 square kilometers with 9.65 million inhabitants (USDS, 2010). The country’s workforce is highly dependent on the services sector, being comprised of the tourism, transportation, communications and finances industries (USDS, 2010). A further 11.5 per cent are employed in construction, 11.3 per cent in agriculture, and 1.5 per cent in mining. The country’s per capita Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is approximately US$4,815 (USDS, 2011), contributing to the Dominican Republic’s status as the second poorest nation in the Caribbean.

Like most countries in Latin America, the Dominican Republic has submitted one national communication to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) with a second one under preparation. Land use change and forestry are large contributors to GHG emissions within the sector. The emission reduction potential is large and several reforestation programs have been initiated. The Dominican Republic does not count with CDM projects in the agricultural sector, thus carbon trading opportunities can be explored. Agriculture is highly vulnerable to extreme weather events, this coupled with problems of land degradation in the country. A greater emphasis on developing and applying adequate insurance mechanisms can be placed for better management of public resources in light of natural disasters in the agriculture sector.

On the adaptation side, the focus is on the potential to build resilience to climate and to increase the adaptive capacity through sustainable management of agriculture and other complementary factors (e.g. financial instruments).


UNDP in the Dominican Republic

The United Nations Development Program (UNDP) has been part of the United Nations System in the Dominican Republic since 1964. All its actions are framed within the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG). Human Development is a process that expands people's options and strengthens human capabilities, to maximize what a person can be and do.

Our actions are part of the Basic Cooperation Agreement (SBAA) signed with the Dominican government on June 11, 1974 and ratified by the National Congress on November 5, 1974, as well as in the Country Program document and the United Nations Assistance Framework (UNDAF 2018-2022) , documents that also establish the link between UNDP and the National Development Strategy (END).

Our work in the Dominican Republic is to promote, together with the Dominican State and society, the formulation and implementation of public policies and the development of capacities, through the management and execution of programs and projects under the principles of integrity, transparency and impartiality, in accordance with international standards and human rights.

UNDP provides technical and operational assistance to countries that request it to achieve sustainable human development. We promote the progress of countries through rigorous and innovative analytical work. In the Dominican Republic, we are also looking for ways to accelerate results through our Accelerator Laboratory and using the enormous potential of data to implement comprehensive solutions to the most urgent challenges. We also work so that the financial system supports sustainable development, aligning public and private investors through the prism of the SDGs. In all facets of our work, we want to ensure that our support generates added value for the country, which is why we harness the power of the digital world and use our Global Policy Network of 17,000 experts in 50 countries to build integrated solutions that lead us to the achievement of the 2030 Agenda.

We have collaborated with the process of democratic consolidation, economic recovery and improvement of the quality of life of the poorest population in the country, through specialized technical assistance and participation in the implementation of the various programs and projects in our four areas of work: Environmental Sustainability and Resilience, Gender Equality, Democratic Governance and Sustainable Human Development.

The resources for the implementation of development projects managed by the UNDP in the country come from:

  1. Allocations made directly from the Regular Resources of the Organization;
  2. Direct contributions provided by the State entities that lead the implementation of the initiatives
  3. Cooperation agreements signed with other actors, including Vertical Funds, Multilateral or Bilateral Cooperation Organizations, or the private sector.

In the Dominican Republic, the UNDP has supported, on average, the execution of public resources equivalent to 0.28% of the annual budget in the last 10 years, which is equivalent to an average annual amount of US$51.2 million (close to two thousand nine hundred million of weights).

Additionally, through the mobilization of international funds, the UNDP has brought to the Dominican Republic more than RD$4,000 million Dominican pesos (US$70 million) in the last 10 years, which have been invested in more than 350 projects in favor of sustainable human development.

These development projects have contributed to the welfare and improvement of services for citizens. Learn more about these projects at  open.undp.org

Sustainable use of natural capital

The UNDP promotes the mainstreaming of environmental sustainability in the development priorities of the Dominican Republic to guarantee the availability of environmental goods and services for economic development and human well-being, contribute to strengthening the governance of natural resources and promote greater capacities to compliance with current laws and regulations. These measures are expected to be expressed in sectoral plans and policies and implemented in the territory (municipalities, protected areas, productive landscapes, hydrographic basins).

Sustainable production and consumption

To help reduce the ecological footprint of the Dominican Republic, which, to date, doubles the availability of resources for sustainable development and improves the quality of the environment, UNDP promotes a more efficient use of natural resources and energy, reducing emissions of harmful gases and waste to ensure that these can be absorbed progressively and sustainably by ecosystems. With this objective, the UNDP proposes innovative solutions and promotes dialogue and collective action of all the actors involved in the waste management chain, including producers, consumers and authorities.

Climate change mitigation and adaptation to its effects

UNDP contributes to the construction of a resilient and carbon neutral development model; including the development of relevant policies and strategies, the generation of information, the promotion of renewable energy sources and the development of adaptation measures that allow reducing the vulnerability of individuals (particularly the most vulnerable: poor people living in danger zones ) and promote ecosystem-based adaptation measures. These actions contribute directly to the goals that the Dominican Republic has set itself to achieve the commitments of the Paris Agreement.

Building resilience to natural disasters

UNDP works to reduce human and territorial vulnerability to extreme natural phenomena. To this end, UNDP promotes the human security approach in all its dimensions and contributes to improving knowledge of existing risk factors in the Dominican Republic in order to understand the multiple threats and develop strategies for their comprehensive management. Additionally, UNDP addresses the risks in urban settlements and promotes central-local coordination in the preparation and prevention of risks. UNDP also acts when an emergency strikes, providing assistance to support the coordination of the response and promote recovery measures.

Country programme document for the Dominican Republic (2018-2022) https://digitallibrary.un.org/record/1291538?ln=en

1. The Dominican Republic first positioned itself as a high human development country1 in 2014 and is currently one of the fastest-growing economies in the Latin American and Caribbean region, with an average gross domestic product (GDP) annual growth rate of 7.2 per cent (2014-2015). The service sector accounts for most of the economic growth (54 per cent), followed by trade, construction, tourism and other economic activities which have limited capacity to create employment.2

2. Poverty has been declining, having recently recovered to levels registered before the 2003 economic crisis.3 At the end of 2015, 32.3 per cent of the population were living in moderate poverty and 7 per cent in extreme poverty,4 with reductions of 26.9 per cent in moderate poverty and 49 per cent in extreme poverty between 2006 and 2015. However, there are still significant gaps which maintain inequalities, mostly gender-based, as protection policies and systems are insufficient. In male-headed households, overall poverty sits at 23.7 per cent, compared to 30.6 per cent for female-headed households. Roughly 40 per cent of the population are in the range of economic vulnerability5 with risk of falling back into poverty due to shocks.

3. The Dominican Republic is still one of the most unequal countries in the region.6 The Gini index has shown minimal distributive improvements that are not proportional to the high economic growth (falling 9.7 per cent between 2000 and 2016). The 2015 Human Development Index (0.722) adjusted for inequality fell by 21.7 per cent. The main sources of inequality are in living standards (28.1 per cent), education (19.9 per cent) and health (16.8 per cent). Sixty-one per cent of the population live in provinces with medium-low or low human development (with almost all border provinces located in these categories),7 where the poorest 20 per cent receive only 6.1 per cent of total national income. According to the National Gender Inequality Index, 47 per cent of the provinces have either middle-high or high gender inequality, showing constraints on women’s human development in terms of economic inclusion,8 political participation,9 physical security and reproductive health.

4. Although national human development dimensions of living standards, education and health exhibit positive trends, constraints remain. Seventy-three per cent of the employed population receives a monthly income equivalent to two minimum wages, with difficulties in covering the basic family basket,10 and less than 7 per cent have managed to advance in income categories.11 There are limitations in the labour market, particularly for youth and women: 47 per cent of employed women work in the informal sector and receive incomes up to 39.4 per cent lower than men. By 2016, the unemployment rate for women (20.9 per cent) was almost triple that of men (8 per cent) and increased for youth 18-29 years old (23.2 per cent). Despite a sustained investment of 4 per cent of GDP since 2013, pre-university education has achieved quality results well below the regional average.12 The maternal mortality ratio and neonatal mortality rate are high (101.8 per 100,000 live births

and 25 per 1,000 live births respectively),13 and health coverage gaps persist at the local level. The national epidemiological profile illustrates challenges in catastrophic and non-communicable diseases (indicating high costs to the health system).

5. In response to these development challenges, the country is integrating the Sustainable Development Goals in national and sectoral plans. A national high-level commission was established with the participation of the Government, civil society and the private sector.14 The UNDP-led rapid integrated assessment identified the interlinkages and gaps between the Goals and national planning instruments, revealing an average alignment of 72 per cent, with a high level of convergence for the goals related to people (87 per cent), prosperity (83 per cent) and peace (78 per cent), but less so for planet (42 per cent). Challenges for achieving the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development include the articulation and implementation of public policies for sustainable development.

6. There are successful experiences of natural resource management initiatives, but the national development vision is based on a perception of their unlimited availability. Alteration, fragmentation and loss of ecosystems and species are central challenges for preserving biodiversity.15 Threats associated with climate change, natural hazards (hydro-meteorological and seismic) and vulnerabilities linked to insularity aggravate the challenges associated with the unsustainable management of natural and water resources, mainly due to inadequate plans and budgets.16

7. Migration to underserved cities has increased human vulnerability. Most of the Dominican population (74.3 per cent) now resides in urban settings17 characterized by uncontrolled and unequal expansion resulting from poor planning. Additionally, a vulnerable and extremely poor population is concentrated in mountain areas and sugar-worker settlements known as bateyes.

8. The institutional and normative framework of the Dominican democracy faces challenges to promote and guarantee social well-being and reduce conflicts. Women’s participation in elective positions is still low despite established quotas to ensure female representation,18 and there is a high rate of gender-based violence.19 Social oversight is lacking, and the use of sustainability safeguards in the design of public policies, institutional reforms and transparency in public management is inadequate.

9. Citizen perceptions of insecurity and obstacles to the effective rule of law undermine confidence in governmental institutions. Forty-nine per cent of the population feels insecure and 29.8 per cent report having been the victim of a crime,20 which together with the perception of corruption in public administration (the country ranks 135 of 167 countries),21 underlines the need to strengthen governance and accountability mechanisms.

10. UNDP has positioned itself as a strategic partner to the Dominican Government in promoting the sustainable human development approach, including through the support to poverty and inequality reduction and the integrated management of natural resources and watersheds. The UNDP contribution to knowledge generation and management and its advocacy for political dialogue, the design of public policies and legal frameworks, with a

focus on human rights and sustainable human development,22 are highly regarded as part of its added value, as is the organization’s ability to mobilize specialized technical expertise and best practices on accountability and transparency.

11. UNDP works with the Government to shape and consolidate the institutional architecture of social policies, emphasizing poverty reduction and the development of human capital, aimed at including all people. Examples include the first permanent human development commission in the Chamber of Deputies, support for the construction of the new multi-annual, results-oriented national budget system, integration of the human rights approach in the National HIV/AIDS Strategic Plan, the Climate Shocks Vulnerability Index and the establishment of the Observatory for Citizen Security.

12. UNDP support has been fundamental to ensure government implementation, compliance and oversight commitments of multilateral environmental agreements23 through technical support based on best practices, country reports and national action plans.

13. Lessons learned from the previous country programme confirm: the need to combat inequalities and ensure sustainable results for institutional strengthening, using a human rights and gender equality perspective in all initiatives;24 and the importance of reinforcing UNDP support for national institutions through expanded and diversified partnerships, at all levels, including the private sector, to influence transformational change and better articulate the sustainable human development paradigm.

Human Development Report 2020

https://hdr.undp.org/en/countries/profiles/DOM#

HDI value and rank

Dominican Republic’s HDI value for 2019 is 0.756— which put the country in the high human development category—positioning it at 88 out of 189 countries and territories. The rank is shared with Azerbaijan. Between 1990 and 2019, Dominican Republic’s HDI value increased from 0.599 to 0.756, an increase of 26.2 percent. Table A reviews Dominican Republic’s progress in each of the HDI indicators. Between 1990 and 2019, Dominican Republic’s life expectancy at birth increased by 7.5 years, mean years of schooling increased by 3.2 years and expected years of schooling increased by 2.7 years. Dominican Republic’s GNI per capita increased by about 196.1 percent between 1990 and 2019.

Inequality-adjusted HDI (IHDI)

Dominican Republic’s HDI for 2019 is 0.756. However, when the value is discounted for inequality, the HDI falls to 0.595, a loss of 21.3 percent due to inequality in the distribution of the HDI dimension indices. El Salvador and Jamaica show losses due to inequality of 21.4 percent and 16.6 percent, respectively. The average loss due to inequality for high HDI countries is 17.9 percent and for Latin America and the Caribbean it is 22.2 percent. The Human inequality coefficient for Dominican Republic is equal to 21.1 percent.

Gender Development Index (GDI)

The GDI is calculated for 167 countries. The 2019 female HDI value for Dominican Republic is 0.759 in contrast with 0.760 for males, resulting in a GDI value of 0.999, placing it into Group 1.2 In comparison, GDI values for El Salvador and Jamaica are 0.975 and 0.994, respectively.

Gender Inequality Index (GII)

Dominican Republic has a GII value of 0.455, ranking it 112 out of 162 countries in the 2019 index. In Dominican Republic, 24.3 percent of parliamentary seats are held by women, and 59.7 percent of adult women have reached at least a secondary level of education compared to 56.1 percent of their male counterparts. For every 100,000 live births, 95.0 women die from pregnancy related causes; and the adolescent birth rate is 94.3 births per 1,000 women of ages 15-19. Female participation in the labour market is 51.4 percent compared to 77.4 for men.

Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI)

The most recent survey data that were publicly available for Dominican Republic’s MPI estimation refer to 2014. In Dominican Republic, 3.9 percent of the population (412 thousand people) are multidimensionally poor while an additional 5.2 percent are classified as vulnerable to multidimensional poverty (551 thousand people). The breadth of deprivation (intensity) in Dominican Republic, which is the average deprivation

score experienced by people in multidimensional poverty, is 38.9 percent. The MPI, which is the share of the population that is multidimensionally poor, adjusted by the intensity of the deprivations, is 0.015. El Salvador and Jamaica have MPIs of 0.032 and 0.018, respectively.
